data.title: Pasting text after a large untokenized text block should not block
data.body: * Download `checker.ts` from https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/blob/296660a2a077c32a2ed41cb762ef530031e56417/src/compiler/checker.ts * open the file and quickly select all and go to the bottom of the file * (tokenization did not have a chance to execute entirely) * paste * observe: VS Code is freezing until all the text is tokenized. I suggest we probe for the last tokenized line and if a large body of text needs to be tokenized to support auto indent, we skip auto indenting. [CPU-20170706T101827.cpuprofile.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1127177/CPU-20170706T101827.cpuprofile.txt) > Note: we should do the same for Enter: #21564

data.title: Improve memory usage for large files
data.body:
e.g. * open the file and wait for ~ 30s --- ### 1. file A Download Loan Data for 2016 Q3 from https://www.lendingclub.com/info/download-data.action | | empty file | 73 MB
99127 lines | actual usage | overhead | overhead per line | |---|---|---|---|---|---| | OSX RESIDENT | 190 MB | 353 MB | 163 MB | 90 MB | 952.0 B | | OSX Heap Snapshot | 50 MB | 138 MB | 88 MB | 15 MB | 158.6 B | --- ### 2. file B Download `checker.ts` from https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/blob/296660a2a077c32a2ed41cb762ef530031e56417/src/compiler/checker.ts Generate a 128x times checker: ```js var fs = require('fs'); var str = fs.readFileSync('checker.ts').toString(); for (var i = 0; i < 7; i++) { str = str + '\n' + str; } fs.writeFileSync('checker-out.ts', str); ``` | | empty file | 177 MB
3171200 lines | actual usage | overhead | overhead per line | |---|---|---|---|---|---| | OSX RESIDENT | 190 MB | 1474 MB | 1284 MB | 1107 MB | 366.0 B | | OSX Heap Snapshot | 50 MB | 716 MB | 666 MB | 489 MB | 161.7 B | --- * OSX shallow size taken by a ModelLine (via Heap Snapshot) - 72 bytes

data.title: Two colons added when completing pseudo-selector in nested scss
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write 
```
.foo { 
    .bar::bef
}
````
2. Tab or enter on the autocomplete suggestion for ::before
3. Result is
```
.foo { 
    .bar::::before
}
````

data.title: Bracket highlight need improvment

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
For mismatched bracket(s), there should be a question mark or another tag before line number.
When the cursor is in a pair of brackets, both half brackets should be listed before the line number.
Also, when the cursor is in a pair of brackets, the brackets should be underlined.

data.title: Add "()" after the function completes
data.body:
Right now, there is only the function name after complete functions.

I tried some plugins for complete, but nothing.

Sublime or other IDE also can do this, and after the function completes, they also move the cursor to brackets, it's very cool!

data.title: Is it possible to format code of specific extension automatically when I open the file in VS Code?
data.body:
For example, If I'm opening a Javascript file in VSCode, whatever formatting it has already should be ignored and VSCode should autoformat it automatically, without using any keyboard shortcut or CMD+Shift+P

I wish to format file as I open it.

data.title: VS Code auto update wrong UI popup and menu entry after update via package manager
data.body:
I'm using Kali Linux and every time When VS Code prompts an update available, It just don't update itself but rather redirects me to the site, makes me download the .deb file and I have to manually install it. This affects the workflow too much. I really love the typescript support that VS Code gives and this issue bothers me a lot. Is there a way/Plugin to do this automatically? 

PS: I saw this issue [#9539](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/9539). I can agree that we can't just allow auto update in the background cuz people may rely on one feature which might break on auto-update, but atleast when the user is willing to update(by going to Help->update or clicking update on the notification) there should be automatic background update.

data.title: wrong tsx syntax highlight
Split Editor Pane's Initial State Should Be Empty
data.body:
As originally requested (and closed) in [issue 29651](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29651), when a user splits their editor pane, the new pane's initial state should be empty.

Currently the file in the active tab is duplicated in the new pane. This doesn't make sense to me. Frequently I open an additional editor pane in Sublime and drag a config file/notes/readme file to it from a location _outside_ of the currently loaded project directory(ies).

Obviously if a user explicitly selects a file to open in a new pane, the new pane should not be empty. I am _not_ talking about that use case.

data.title: Split Editor Key Bindings Should Reset Horizontal Space
data.body:
When a user is able to define multiple keybindings as [requested in issue 30166](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30166), each split editor keybinding should reset the horizontal space to an evenly distributed percentage: 100% / editor pane count.

Assuming I have defined `alt+shift+2` as the keybinding to open 2 editor panes, if I drag one pane to an 80% width (the second editor therefore being 20%), then click `alt+shift+2`, each editor pane should revert to a 50% horizontal width.

data.title: Allow Multiple Key Bindings for Split Editor
data.body:
Originally reported (and closed) [in issue 29651](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29651), I'd like to be able to define separate key bindings for each split editor, ie:

- `alt+shift+1` collapses to 1 editor pane

- `alt+shift+2` expands or collapses to 2 editor panes

- `alt+shift+3` expands or collapses to 3 editor panes

This is how Sublime Text operates. I use the each unique binding frequently in ST, depending on the project.

data.title: WorkspaceConfiguration.update doesn't work on non-existant settings, but inspect does.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1 and 1.14.0-Insiders.
- OS Version: Windows (probably Linux/Mac too).

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use some extension code that calls WorkspaceConfiguration.inspect on a setting that exists in the settings.json, but isn't valid (e.g. C_Cpp.foo) and then use WorkspaceConfiguration.update with a value of undefined.

Bug: The update call silently fails, so extensions are unable to remove bogus settings from the settings.json via the vscode WorkspaceConfiguration API, even though that API reports the bogus setting from the inspection call.

NOTE: We're trying to remove a setting we previously supported, but update doesn't work unless the setting still exists in our package.json. What do you recommend we do?

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Fix 30162: add to .git ignore doesn't add new line
data.body: Fix #30162 Bringing some of the logic back again to ensure new line appends are correct.

data.title: Prefer most broad TypeScript project root when open js/ts files
data.body:
**Bug**
For folders:

```
project/
    main.js
    jsconfig.json
    sub/
          sub.js
```

When `project` and `project/sub` are opened as root folders.

Open `sub.js` and try using a global from `main.js`

**Expected**
Globals are found in `sub.js` since it is part of the `project/jsconfig.json` project

**Actual**
We currently do not load the `project/jsconfig.json` until a file from `project/*` is opened. This is caused by us telling typescript not to look for config files up past `project/sub` when `sub.js` is opened

**Proposal**
We should instead tell typescript not to look beyond the highest level project root. In this case, that would be `project` for `sub.js`

data.title: add to .git ignore doesn't add new line
data.body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1487073/27889367-df734dd8-61a0-11e7-96e0-7901282ed175.png)

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  open a workspace with a `.gitignore` or add a `.gitignore` to the workspace
2. make sure there is no blank line at the end of the file. mine looks like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1487073/27889402-065122d6-61a1-11e7-9aca-b26403e03582.png)

3. make a change to a file, open the SCC viewlet, right click on a file and use the command "Add File to .gitignore"

Result: .gitingore file is opened, but the file you added is appended to the last line in the file, not on a new line. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1487073/27889425-32845b02-61a1-11e7-82df-424a878b04a9.png)

data.title: add API for tracking the current debug session
data.body:
add API for tracking the current debug session:
```ts
/**
 * The currently active debug session or `undefined`. The active debug session is the one
 * represented by the debug action floating window or the one currently shown in the drop down menu of the debug action floating window.
 * If no debug session is active, the value is `undefined`.
 */
export const activeDebugSession: DebugSession | undefined;

/**
 * An [event](#Event) which fires when the [active debug session](#debug.activeDebugSession)
 * has changed. *Note* that the event also fires when the active debug session changes
 * to `undefined`.
 */
export const onDidChangeActiveDebugSession: Event<DebugSession | undefined>;
```

data.title: Windows terminal session names don't change when launching a shell from the initial shell
data.body:
Running cmd.exe inside powershell for example will always show powershell.exe as the terminal session name in the dropdown.

See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29879#issuecomment-312051800 for a possible solution utilizing `wmic.exe`.

Follow up: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/30070
